title: What is it like to live and work in Silicon Valley? - Quora

response.answer_text: I moved from Ohio to Boston, stayed only one year, and then decided to go West. Many people said I would fit right into the Silicon Valley. Well, they were right. I arrived in the Silicon Valley in 1991 and never left. It’s because: A. Home set-up: I’m in a house in a cul de sac. (We just paid off our house. Awesome, huh?) I was offered a very nice position “back East” at a large corporation but declined because of our neighborhood, school system and house. We’re set up here. B. Weather: there’s no humidity. I grew up in snow, ice and humidity. Before I left Boston I spent a winter scraping ice off of my windshield. It is fun playing in the snow but I don’t want to work in it. C. Tech/VC center of the world: I’m in the tech business and many tech businesses are here. It’s easier to get clients here. Also, international clients like hiring me because they need a rep that’s in the Silicon Valley. If I left I’d lose that edge. The majority of the world’s VCs are HQed near Stanford U which is close to me. D. The can-do attitude reigns here: people get massive support in doing big things like starting businesses and running marathons. There are many CEOs and founders nearby where we live. People compare notes about running companies. I feel right at home. In summary, the people in the Silicon Valley feel a positive spirit that’s hard to match in other places I’ve lived. Tech company leaders like it because it’s easier to hire tech workers like engineers. By the way I didn’t mention the negative stuff because I am speaking from personal experience. As the saying goes, “It’s all good.” ###

I lived and worked in Silicon Valley as a marketing and communications writer (with emphasis on technical writing) since 1998 [http://linkedin.com/in/theoknock]; I bought (and lost) my own home here, and have lived in both San Jose and each and every one of its satellite cities. Accordingly, I can give you a fair estimation of what it may be like for you to live here, even without knowing your race or economic class—the top two factors determining the quality of your life in the Valley. In order to achieve that, first read this: READER | Did your demons follow you to Indiana? Afterwards, gauge your emotional state. That’s what it’s like here: shocking, scary. Being here would give plenty of cause for your friends to worry, and might even estrange you from your family. Nobody wants to be related to the problems that are born here.
